title: How to Choose the Proper Lighting for a Kitchen

steps.headline: Identify the work areas in your kitchen.
steps.description: Task lighting are direct beams of light that illuminate a designated work area. These could include prep stations for making coffee or using the cutting board, sinks, desks or tables.

steps.headline: Select the areas that are directly above your work stations.
Install lighting fixtures above those areas.
Identify the central place in the room where you want to place your main fixture.
steps.description: Ambient lighting is powerful enough to create a diffused light that reaches into spaces like cabinets, the refrigerator or the kitchen table.

steps.headline: Visit a lighting store to get an idea of the styles that are on the market.
steps.description: Large fixtures can be made with iron, plastic, ceramics, glass and antlers and more.

steps.headline: Choose a fixture that goes with your overall décor.
steps.description: Unless you plan to recess a large fixture, you will want to be assured of the lighting quality and aesthetic look before buying.

steps.headline: Identify features that you would like to show off.
steps.description:
Accent lighting draws the eyes to a certain painting or architectural element in your kitchen. For example, if you have a beautiful collection of china arranged on an open cupboard, you may want to highlight it. Consider lighting above your cabinets if you have high ceilings. This will give a classy tone to the room and make it look large and warm. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/6\/68\/Choose-the-Proper-Lighting-for-a-Kitchen-Step-7Bullet1.jpg\/v4-460px-Choose-the-Proper-Lighting-for-a-Kitchen-Step-7Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/6\/68\/Choose-the-Proper-Lighting-for-a-Kitchen-Step-7Bullet1.jpg\/v4-760px-Choose-the-Proper-Lighting-for-a-Kitchen-Step-7Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"}

steps.headline: Research track lighting and low-voltage linear lights.
steps.description: Many of these can be installed onto the ceiling.

steps.headline: Choose energy efficient bulbs.
steps.description: Accent lighting usually requires more smaller bulbs than the larger task and accent lights, because they have less of an influence on your everyday tasks.

text:
Task Lighting Identify the work areas in your kitchen. Task lighting are direct beams of light that illuminate a designated work area. These could include prep stations for making coffee or using the cutting board, sinks, desks or tables. Select the areas that are directly above your work stations. Install lighting fixtures above those areas. Some people use halogen bulbs, as they produce a light glow, but they aren't too harsh. Others use fluorescent bulbs in all fixtures because they are energy efficient. A popular choice for task lighting is under cabinet lights. These can be installed when you get new cabinets, or they can be screwed into place later. If you like this idea and you are getting new cabinetry, make sure it leaves enough room at the bottom to shed light on your work area. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/93/Choose-the-Proper-Lighting-for-a-Kitchen-Step-3Bullet1.jpg/v4-460px-Choose-the-Proper-Lighting-for-a-Kitchen-Step-3Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/93/Choose-the-Proper-Lighting-for-a-Kitchen-Step-3Bullet1.jpg/v4-760px-Choose-the-Proper-Lighting-for-a-Kitchen-Step-3Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Another choice is pendant lights that hang from the ceiling. Many beautiful modern fixtures hang from a single chord to shed light on an area. You can adjust this lighting to the right height over the sink or stove. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/24/Choose-the-Proper-Lighting-for-a-Kitchen-Step-3Bullet2.jpg/v4-460px-Choose-the-Proper-Lighting-for-a-Kitchen-Step-3Bullet2.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/24/Choose-the-Proper-Lighting-for-a-Kitchen-Step-3Bullet2.jpg/v4-760px-Choose-the-Proper-Lighting-for-a-Kitchen-Step-3Bullet2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} A third option is to recess lights into the ceiling, directly above work stations. They give broad, even lighting to your work. This is best done with a home or kitchen remodel because the electrician must wire them extensively into the walls. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/31/Choose-the-Proper-Lighting-for-a-Kitchen-Step-3Bullet3.jpg/v4-460px-Choose-the-Proper-Lighting-for-a-Kitchen-Step-3Bullet3.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/31/Choose-the-Proper-Lighting-for-a-Kitchen-Step-3Bullet3.jpg/v4-760px-Choose-the-Proper-Lighting-for-a-Kitchen-Step-3Bullet3.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Ambient Lighting Identify the central place in the room where you want to place your main fixture. Ambient lighting is powerful enough to create a diffused light that reaches into spaces like cabinets, the refrigerator or the kitchen table. Visit a lighting store to get an idea of the styles that are on the market. Large fixtures can be made with iron, plastic, ceramics, glass and antlers and more. Choose a fixture that goes with your overall décor. Unless you plan to recess a large fixture, you will want to be assured of the lighting quality and aesthetic look before buying. Accent Lighting Identify features that you would like to show off. Accent lighting draws the eyes to a certain painting or architectural element in your kitchen. For example, if you have a beautiful collection of china arranged on an open cupboard, you may want to highlight it. Consider lighting above your cabinets if you have high ceilings. This will give a classy tone to the room and make it look large and warm. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/68/Choose-the-Proper-Lighting-for-a-Kitchen-Step-7Bullet1.jpg/v4-460px-Choose-the-Proper-Lighting-for-a-Kitchen-Step-7Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/68/Choose-the-Proper-Lighting-for-a-Kitchen-Step-7Bullet1.jpg/v4-760px-Choose-the-Proper-Lighting-for-a-Kitchen-Step-7Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Research track lighting and low-voltage linear lights. Many of these can be installed onto the ceiling. Choose energy efficient bulbs. Accent lighting usually requires more smaller bulbs than the larger task and accent lights, because they have less of an influence on your everyday tasks.
